H0.text: Fatty acids are the acids that are structural components of many lipids and may be saturated or unsaturated.

H1.text: Fundamental acids are the structural components of many lipids and may be saturated or unsaturated.

H2.text: Ionic acids are the structural components of many lipids and may be saturated or unsaturated.

H3.text: Carbonic acids are the structural components of many lipids and may be saturated or unsaturated.

A4.text: fatty acids are also important components of the phospholipids that form the phospholipid bilayers out of which all the membranes of the cell are constructed (the cell wall, and the membranes that enclose all the organelles within the cells, such as the nucleus, the mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, and the Golgi apparatus).

A5.text: When synthesis is complete the free fatty acids are nearly always combined with glycerol (three fatty acids to one glycerol molecule) to form triglycerides, the main storage form of fatty acids, and thus of energy in animals.
